instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to investigate the feasibility and potentiality of presymptomatic detection of tobacco disease?
Output: Successive projections algorithm was used for effective wavelengths (EWs) selection in combination with hyperspectral imaging, variable selection methods, and machine-learning classifiers to investigate the feasibility and potentiality of presymptomatic detection of tobacco disease.

instruction: What metric was chosen to investigate the feasibility and potentiality of presymptomatic detection of tobacco disease?
Output: The metric chosen to investigate the feasibility and potentiality of presymptomatic detection of tobacco disease was classification accuracy.

instruction: What machine-learning algorithms were used for disease detection and classification in the study on presymptomatic detection of tobacco disease using hyperspectral imaging?
Output: The machine-learning algorithms used for disease detection and classification in the study on presymptomatic detection of tobacco disease using hyperspectral imaging were back propagation neural network (BPNN), extreme learning machine (ELM), and least squares support vector machine (LS-SVM) models.

instruction: Can hyperspectral imaging, variable selection method, and machine-learning classifiers be used to achieve presymptomatic detection of tobacco disease with higher accuracy compared to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, hyperspectral imaging, variable selection method, and machine-learning classifiers can be used to achieve presymptomatic detection of tobacco disease with higher accuracy compared to traditional methods. The study found that using hyperspectral imaging combined with the variable selection method and machine-learning classifiers resulted in classification accuracies above 80% for detecting and classifying disease stages. The chemometric models with data fusion, which incorporated both effective wavelengths (EWs) and texture features, achieved even better results with accuracies up to 95%. This indicates that these advanced techniques have the potential to accurately identify infected leaves in a shorter period of time compared to traditional methods that rely on visible symptoms of infection.
